sub_title: Associate Professor (Tenured) at Leiden Institute of Chemistry
summary:
My scientific career focuses on the study of heterogeneously catalyzed processes on the atomic scale using surface science techniques and density functional theory. I am interested in the fundamental aspects that govern physical and chemical processes taking place at the surfaces of nano-sized materials.
I study different chemical reactions that are enabled or enhanced by the use of catalysts. Examples of these chemical reactions are H2 dissociation, CO oxidation and chlorine production. Using a combination of surface science techniques under ultrahigh vacuum conditions and in situ operando methods I follow the changes of catalytic surfaces before, during and after reaction, while at the same time measuring the reactants and products. This combination enables me to link surface morphology to catalytic reactivity.
When more fundamental insights in these processes are gained, better catalysts can be developed, thereby saving energy, resources and money.

Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}, 'end': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2013}}, 'company': 'Leiden Institute of Physics, Leiden University', 'description': 'Using operando scanning probe microscopy, I study the relationship between structure and reactivity for model catalysts in the Deacon process, the catalytic oxidation of HCl to produce chlorine. Currently, in the chemical industry Cl2 is mainly produced by electrolysis, using large amounts of electricity. This makes this very important process environment-unfriendly and expensive. Another possible production route is via the use of a catalyst. There is currently one catalyst available that can compete with Cl2 production via electrolysis. This catalyst, however, is based on ruthenium, a scarce and expensive material. My goal is to unravel the reaction mechanisms to understand the superiority of this metal. When this fundamental insight is gained, catalysts that are based on cheaper and more abundant materials can be developed.
